page.title: 17GEOLOGY OF NORTH FAREHAM
page.content: The rocks of this area change in a northerly progression.The south of the block is upper chalk from the Cretaceous Period,which is soft white chalk with flint nodules.This chalk has been quarried for hundreds of years.Next in the progression, parallel to the chalk are the Reading Beds which is a clay mixed with sand; this gives rise to an easily worked loam soil.Next,and again parallel,lies the London Clay,an impermeable rock, which produces a heavy soil suitable for cereal growing.In the north of the block,capping the higher ground,are outcrops of Bagshot Sands,notably on Wickham Common.
